text: When I went to Pix this weekend I asked how they manage their cellar. The server told me that the owner comes in daily to manage it. Could be a good real life test case to reduce friction

<@U0B9N0HF0|rob> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/rob/F378A9196/sommely_sbir_budget_working_copy.numbers|NSF SBIR Phase I Proposal Budget Template> and commented: Open items: Materials and Suplies, Publications Costs/documentation/dissemination, consultant services, computer services, Indirect costs (independent R&D, patents, sales and marketing, business development, and manufacturing and production expenses)

file.name: Sommely_SBIR_Budget_Working copy.numbers
file.title: NSF SBIR Phase I Proposal Budget Template

initial_comment.comment: Open items: Materials and Suplies, Publications Costs/documentation/dissemination, consultant services, computer services, Indirect costs (independent R&D, patents, sales and marketing, business development, and manufacturing and production expenses)

text: <@U0K8ZSHN0> note that Indirect Costs *exclude* Independent Research and Development, patent, sales and marketing, business development and manufacturing and production (not include)
so we cant use the money to produce material to test out our research?
Trying to figure that out now

Looks like Publications costs/documentation and distribution are not allowed in Phase I. Nor is travel (beyond required attendance at a SBIR/STTR Phase I Grantee workshop), nor is participant support costs
Trying to figure out where manufacturing and production goes
Still looking, but good to note that on line under materials and supplies: Categories that include costs less than $1,000 do not have to be itemized.

Here are some areas to be aware of it in our general write-up with regards to: specific aims, significance, innovation, approach, etc. <https://www.nimh.nih.gov/funding/grant-writing-and-application-process/common-mistakes-in-writing-applications.shtml>

attachments.title: NIMH » Common Mistakes in Writing Applications
attachments.text: The five review criteria for most NIH grant applications are: significance, approach, innovation, investigator, and environment.
attachments.fallback: NIMH » Common Mistakes in Writing Applications

text: If my reading is correct, Phase I is not to support biz dev, sales or marketing, manufacturing or production, patents or independent R&D (hiring firms) :confused: In materials and supplies we provide an itemized list of materials and supplies (over $1,000) Items with a total line item cost of over $5,000 should be noted with quotes and include seperate pricing documentation and justification in a seperate doc that we upload with the application

<@U026NB2U2> Of note on the Marc consultant costs: Consultant Rate. The reimbursement rates for consultants are a direct cost that cannot exceed the daily equivalent of the rate paid to an Executive Level IV Federal employee. As of January 2013, that amount is $600 per day. The consulting rate under the solicitation can be a maximum of $600 per day (NSF defines a day as 8 hours).

However, *_No person who is an *equity holder, employee, or officer of the proposing small business* may be paid as a consultant unless an exception is recommended by the Program Director and approved by the Division Director for the Division of Industrial Innovation and Partnerships._
Is the money only to pay salaries?

An materials. I think we try and use the "Other" line item and put in the Budget Justifcation something along the lines of: Sommely will contract ABC Boards Inc. to assemble 1,000 "smart" caps and 10 base hubs. The rate for this service is $300 and it is estimated to take 20 hrs.. Total cost is 300*20= $6,000.

Speaking of budget justification. I have put one together here with the fields we need to fill in and a sample budget justification starting on pg. 2 <https://docs.google.com/a/uncorkedstudios.com/document/d/1OY8oTQINEZcgI1loHo74P5FUBnuMTj_pMTOvSqRapO8/edit?usp=sharing>
